knowledges.speaker: Monica

_examples: I asked about their special today
He had to ask directions several times

synsets.definition: make a request or demand for something to somebody
_examples: She asked him for a loan

synsets.definition: direct or put; seek an answer to
_examples: ask a question
We require our secretary to be on time
Aren't we asking too much of these children?
I expect my students to arrive in time for their lessons

synsets.definition: address a question to and expect an answer from
_examples: Ask your teacher about trigonometry
The children asked me about their dead grandmother

synsets.definition: require as useful, just, or proper
_examples: It takes nerve to do what she did
success usually requires hard work
This job asks a lot of patience and skill
This position demands a lot of personal sacrifice
This dinner calls for a spectacular dessert
This intervention does not postulate a patient's consent

synsets.definition: require or ask for as a price or condition
_examples: He is asking $200 for the table
The kidnappers are asking a million dollars in return for the release of their hostage

knowledges.origin_sent: Can I ask you guys a question?

knowledges.speaker: Chandler

synsets.definition: have or possess, either in a concrete or an abstract sense
_examples: She has $1,000 in the bank
He has got two beautiful daughters
She holds a Master's degree from Harvard
This restaurant features the most famous chefs in France

synsets.definition: go through (mental or physical states or experiences)
_examples: get an idea
experience vertigo
get nauseous
receive injuries
have a feeling
He owns three houses in Florida
How many cars does she have?

synsets.definition: cause to move; cause to be in a certain position or condition
_examples: He got his squad on the ball
This let me in for a big surprise
He got a girl into trouble

synsets.definition: serve oneself to, or consume regularly
_examples: Have another bowl of chicken soup!
I don't take sugar in my coffee

synsets.definition: have a personal or business relationship with someone
_examples: have a postdoc
have an assistant
have a lover
hold a reception
have, throw, or make a party
give a course
I have two years left
I don't have any money left
They have two more years before they retire
What do we have here?
Now we have a fine mess
The stocks had a fast run-up
She has arthritis

synsets.definition: cause to do; cause to act in a specified manner
_examples: The ads induced me to buy a VCR
My children finally got me to buy a computer
My wife made me buy a new sofa

synsets.definition: receive willingly something given or offered
_examples: The only girl who would have him was the miller's daughter
I won't have this dog in my house!
Please accept my present

synsets.definition: get something; come into possession of
_examples: receive payment
receive a gift
receive letters from the front
She suffered a fracture in the accident
He had an insulin shock after eating three candy bars
She got a bruise on her leg
He got his arm broken in the scuffle
Nicklaus had a 70
The Brazilian team got 4 goals
She made 29 points that day
My wife had twins yesterday!
He had taken this woman when she was most vulnerable

knowledges.origin_sent: I personally could have a gallon of Alan.
